node.title: The West is staring down Chinese power — but do we know what's worth fighting for?
node.description: To talk about notions of honour or society can seem hopelessly conservative today, even reactionary. But the question remains: what to we replace them with, asks Stan Grant.

node.title: 'I felt like a prisoner': Here's what it's like to live under a conservatorship like Britney Spears
node.description: Jenny Hatch is among more than a million Americans who've lived under strict legal arrangements where their every move was controlled by someone else. Now that the Britney Spears case has shone the spotlight on conservatorships, advocates are pushing for change.

node.title: Two billion vaccines, a lofty goal and unmet promises: How rich nations have failed the world
node.description: More booster shots have now been administered in high income countries than the total number of doses given in low income countries since the pandemic began.

node.title: Flooding and Nuclear Waste Eat Away at a Tribe’s Ancestral Home
node.description: The federal government allowed a stockpile of spent fuel on a Minnesota reservation to balloon even as a dam project whittled down the amount of livable land.

node.title: Firefighter's vaccination mandate deadline pushed back
node.description: The deadline for firefighters in New Zealand to get vaccinated against Covid-19 has been pushed back two weeks.

node.title: Three more positive cases of Covid-19 confirmed in Taupō
node.description: Three more positive Covid cases have been confirmed in Taupō, with new locations of interest linked to the cases as far south as Wairarapa.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 175 new community cases reported in NZ
node.description: There have been 175 new community cases reported in New Zealand today, with 93 people now in hospital.

node.title: Chris Christie Wants the Post-Trump G.O.P. to Move Past 2020
node.description: In a new book and in an interview, Mr. Christie says that if the former president wants to be a positive force, “he’s got to let this other stuff go.”

node.title: How the U.S. Hid an Airstrike That Killed Dozens of Civilians in Syria
node.description: The military never conducted an independent investigation into a 2019 bombing on the last bastion of the Islamic State, despite concerns about a secretive commando force.

node.title: 'You Can Hardly Buy Groceries': Inflation Complaints Grow as Gloomy Sentiment Hurts Biden
node.description: "Before, you'd go to the store, and if you had $100, you could buy four bags of groceries and be happy. Now, you're lucky to get a bag," a consumer told NPR.

node.title: Johnson & Johnson, Iconic Company Under Pressure, Plans to Split in Two
node.description: The 135-year-old company announced plans to divide itself into a consumer products business and a medical company.

node.title: Oregon School District Fined Thousands of Dollars for Not Upholding State Mask Mandate
node.description: The Adrian School District was hit with more than $11,000 in fees after the state investigated four health violations.

node.title: 1-Year-Old Shot in Head in Chicago as City Nears 700 Homicides in 2021
node.description: The boy was caught in the crossfire when four men seemingly targeted another man exiting a gas station nearby on Chicago's South Side.

node.title: Glasgow Climate Talks Are Down to the Wire on Money, Ambition and Fossil Fuels
node.description: At COP26, negotiators from about 200 countries worked overnight, hashing out differences in the quest for a new global climate agreement

node.title: Silver Ferns in tough draw at Birmingham 2022
node.description: The Silver Ferns have been confirmed in the same pool as England in next year's Commonwealth Games.

node.title: All Blacks captain Whitelock itching to renew rivalry with Ireland
node.description: All Blacks skipper Sam Whitelock is looking forward to another chapter in a growing rivalry with Ireland.

node.title: Deere Reaches Third Tentative Deal With Union in Attempt to End Strike
node.description: About 10,000 workers primarily in Iowa and Illinois have been out since Oct. 14. They rejected two previous contract proposals negotiated by the United Automobile Workers.

node.title: Mechanic converts classic cars into electric vehicles
node.description: "Once they get in the car and it's converted, you get a big easy grin and that's it, they're never going back," said Matthew Quitter.

node.title: What the ‘Halloween’ Movies Mean
node.description: These films play with the fears of middle-class white Americans.

node.title: Bill Maher Deplores Claim 'White Ignorance' Helped Youngkin Win Virginia Governor's Race
node.description: "I believe in a colorblind society. That's not where woke is, okay?" the 'Real Time' host said on his show Friday.

node.title: Video of Mark Meadows Complaining About Subpoenas Being Ignored Resurfaces Amid Indictment Threat
node.description: In a 2018 interview with Fox News, the then GOP congressman complained that Congress had been "stonewalled," adding "it's all about transparency."

node.title: Medicare's "Part B" premium will jump by $21.60 a month next year
node.description: Officials say a new Alzheimer's drug is responsible for about half of that.

node.title: Media for Parents that Doesn’t Make Me Hate Life
node.description: Some of it is worth your time.

node.title: How to Teach a Little Girl to Love Her Brown Skin
node.description: “I don’t like my skin color,” my beautiful, brown-skinned daughter told me. “I wish my skin was lighter. It’s prettier.”

node.title: Why I Can’t Quit Extreme Workouts
node.description: I like workouts that burn, workouts that sear, workouts that leave me on the ground gasping for air.

node.title: It’s Time to End the Pandemic Emergency at the Border
node.description: Title 42 was supposed to be an emergency measure. It’s time to end its use.

node.title: Unarmed Drivers Killed by Police in Traffic Stops
node.description: Readers discuss a Times investigative report and offer suggestions to reduce the fatalities.

node.title: State Senator Who Fought Vaccine Mandate Stuck in El Salvador With COVID
node.description: Washington state lawmaker Doug Ericksen was a critic of emergency pandemic orders of Governor Jay Inslee.

node.title: Fourth Stimulus Check Update: Petitions Near 4M Signatures as California Sends Out Payments
node.description: Millions of Americans are urging the federal government provide $2,000 reoccurring monthly payments.

node.title: Commissioner to investigate Kāinga Ora over political neutrality
node.description: Government housing agency Kāinga Ora will be investigated by Public Service Commissioner Peter Hughes after it funded advertising content featuring a Labour candidate.

node.title: Julian Assange to Wed in Prison in Britain
node.description: The WikiLeaks founder, who is battling extradition to the United States on espionage charges, has been granted permission to marry Stella Moris in the London prison where he has been held since 2019.

node.title: Portugal bars companies from contacting employees off hours and requires other protections for remote work.
node.description: A new law, passed on Friday and in effect this weekend, is one of the world’s boldest efforts to regulate the remote work that the pandemic forced on many in the industrialized world.

node.title: Video Shows Man Stealing ATM by Tying It to Pickup Truck, Destroying Entrance of Salon
node.description: "I was blown away...it's insane," one employee of the business said after the destructive theft.

node.title: This year's Rockefeller Center Christmas Tree arrives in New York City
node.description: The tree — coming from Maryland for the first time ever — will be wrapped in more than 50,000 lights and lit on December 1.

node.title: Steve Bannon Predicts Constitutional Crisis as He's Indicted: 'Suck on This'
node.description: "We're going to decertify the [2020] electors," the Trump ally vowed.

node.title: COVID booster shots allowed for all adults in California, Colorado, New Mexico
node.description: The three states have some of the nation's highest rates of new infections.

node.title: How Tiny Fish Use Great White Sharks as Giant Scrubbing Brushes
node.description: Tiny fish use the ocean's deadliest predator's rough skin to exfoliate, just don't rub them up the wrong way.

node.title: Oklahoma’s governor puts an opponent of vaccine mandates in charge of the National Guard.
node.description: The governor, Kevin Stitt, is one of a number of Republican state officials across the country who has been fighting against President Biden’s vaccine mandates.

node.title: Doctor Charged With False Report to Summon Helicopter on Denali
node.description: Federal prosecutors said the climber called rescuers to say that two other people on the mountain, the tallest in North America, were having a medical emergency. But it was a ruse.

node.title: SpaceX launches 53 more Starlink satellites for internet constellation
node.description: SpaceX has now launched 1,844 Starlinks since the first two prototypes were sent up in 2018.

node.description: In a new book and in an interview, Mr. Christie says that if the former president wants to be a positive force, “he’s got to let this other stuff go.”

node.title: 7 iPhone Upgrades from Nomad Goods That Will Earn You a Ton of Compliments
node.description: Your iPhone is pretty darned awesome, but these 7 upgrades from Nomad Goods make it even better.

node.title: Vladimir Putin Says Russia Black Sea Exercises Were Rejected to Avoid Escalation With NATO
node.description: The Russian president told a TV interview that alliance posed a "serious challenge" in the Black Sea region.

node.title: Video: Driver So Drunk He Overtakes Police Car

node.title: Over 30,000 union nurses, support staff plan to strike on Monday

node.title: For Terminal Patients, the Barrier to Aid in Dying Can Be a State Line
node.description: Complex restrictions are preventing patients from accessing medical aid in dying, even in states where it is allowed. New legal and legislative efforts are pushing to change that.

node.title: Business Schools Respond to a Flood of Interest in E.S.G.
node.description: As the number of jobs focused on environmental, social and governance issues grows, M.B.A. programs are updating their courses to meet demand from students and recruiters.

node.title: Kizik Lima Review: The Laziest Shoes Made for People Who Care
node.description: Kizik developed hands-free shoes with a pop-up heel. The shoes can be slipped on, but, most importantly, they still look good.

node.title: Why These Friendly Cat Breeds Can't Get Enough Attention
node.description: Knowing which cats are the friendliest can be difficult, and sometimes finding a more affectionate cat can mean your feline wants a little too much attention.

node.title: Sara Duterte is running for vice-president of the Philippines, and she may have to take her father on
node.description: The popular longtime mayor's candidacy for vice-president comes as a surprise because opinion polls show her ahead in the race for preferred presidential candidate.

node.title: Dying Dog Who Sits Next to Sign Saying She Needs 'Extra Love' Breaks Hearts
node.description: Sparkle the dog is a "neighborhood fixture," but her fans are heartbroken after she was diagnosed with terminal cancer.
